# Fermentation in winemaking

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Mthomebrew_must.JPG/350px-
Mthomebrew_must.JPG)](/wiki/File:Mthomebrew_must.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Mthomebrew_must.JPG "Enlarge")

Fermenting [must](/wiki/Must "Must")

The process of **[fermentation](/wiki/Fermentation_\(biochemistry\)
"Fermentation \(biochemistry\)")** in **[winemaking](/wiki/Winemaking
"Winemaking")** turns [grape juice](/wiki/Grape_juice "Grape juice") into an
[alcoholic beverage](/wiki/Alcoholic_beverage "Alcoholic beverage"). During
fermentation, [yeasts](/wiki/Yeast "Yeast") transform [sugars](/wiki/Sugar
"Sugar") present in the juice into [ethanol](/wiki/Ethanol "Ethanol") and
[carbon dioxide](/wiki/Carbon_dioxide "Carbon dioxide") (as a [by-
product](/wiki/By-product "By-product")). In winemaking, the
[temperature](/wiki/Temperature "Temperature") and speed of fermentation are
important considerations as well as the levels of [oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen
"Oxygen") present in the [must](/wiki/Must "Must") at the start of the
fermentation. The risk of [stuck fermentation](/wiki/Stuck_fermentation "Stuck
fermentation") and the development of several [wine faults](/wiki/Wine_fault
"Wine fault") can also occur during this stage, which can last anywhere from 5
to 14 days for _primary fermentation_ and potentially another 5 to 10 days for
a _[secondary fermentation](/wiki/Secondary_fermentation_\(wine\) "Secondary
fermentation \(wine\)")_. Fermentation may be done in stainless steel tanks,
which is common with many white wines like [Riesling](/wiki/Riesling
"Riesling"), in an open wooden vat, inside a [wine barrel](/wiki/Wine_barrel
"Wine barrel") and inside the [wine bottle](/wiki/Wine_bottle "Wine bottle")
itself as in [the production](/wiki/Sparkling_wine_production "Sparkling wine
production") of many [sparkling wines](/wiki/Sparkling_wine "Sparkling
wine").[1][2]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_in_winemaking&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

See also: [History of wine](/wiki/History_of_wine "History of wine")

The natural occurrence of fermentation means it was probably first observed
long ago by humans.[3] The earliest uses of the word "fermentation" in
relation to winemaking was in reference to the apparent "boiling" within the
must that came from the [anaerobic
reaction](/wiki/Fermentation_\(biochemistry\) "Fermentation \(biochemistry\)")
of the yeast to the [sugars](/wiki/Sugars_in_wine "Sugars in wine") in the
grape juice and the release of carbon dioxide. The [Latin](/wiki/Latin
"Latin") _fervere_ means, literally, _to boil_. In the mid-19th century,
[Louis Pasteur](/wiki/Louis_Pasteur "Louis Pasteur") noted the connection
between yeast and the process of the fermentation in which the yeast act as
catalyst and mediator through a series of a reaction that convert sugar into
alcohol. The discovery of the [Embden–Meyerhof–Parnas](/wiki/Glycolysis
"Glycolysis") pathway by [Gustav Embden](/wiki/Gustav_Embden "Gustav Embden"),
[Otto Fritz Meyerhof](/wiki/Otto_Fritz_Meyerhof "Otto Fritz Meyerhof") and
[Jakub Karol Parnas](/wiki/Jakub_Karol_Parnas "Jakub Karol Parnas") in the
early 20th century contributed more to the understanding of the complex
chemical processes involved in the conversion of sugar to alcohol.[4]

##
Process[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_in_winemaking&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Process")]

See also: [Yeast in winemaking](/wiki/Yeast_in_winemaking "Yeast in
winemaking")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Yeast_on_grapes.jpg/220px-
Yeast_on_grapes.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yeast_on_grapes.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Yeast_on_grapes.jpg "Enlarge")

"Bloom", visible as a dusting on the berries

In winemaking, there are distinctions made between _ambient yeast_ s which are
naturally present in wine cellars, vineyards and on the grapes themselves
(sometimes known as a grape's "bloom" or "blush") and _cultured yeast_ which
are specifically isolated and inoculated for use in winemaking. The most
common [genera](/wiki/Genus "Genus") of wild yeasts found in winemaking
include _[Candida](/wiki/Candida_\(genus\) "Candida \(genus\)"),
[Klöckera/Hanseniaspora](/w/index.php?title=Kl%C3%B6ckera/Hanseniaspora&action=edit&redlink=1
"Klöckera/Hanseniaspora \(page does not exist\)"),
[Metschnikowiaceae](/wiki/Metschnikowiaceae "Metschnikowiaceae"),
[Pichia](/wiki/Pichia "Pichia")_ and
_[Zygosaccharomyces](/wiki/Zygosaccharomyces "Zygosaccharomyces")_. Wild
yeasts can produce high-quality, unique-flavored wines; however, they are
often unpredictable and may introduce less desirable traits to the wine, and
can even contribute to spoilage. It should be noted that few yeast, and lactic
and acetic acid bacterial colonies naturally live on the surface of grapes,[5]
but traditional wine makers, particularly in Europe, advocate use of ambient
yeast as a characteristic of the region's _[terroir](/wiki/Terroir "Terroir")_
; nevertheless, many winemakers prefer to control fermentation with
predictable cultured yeast. The cultured yeasts most commonly used in
winemaking belong to the _[Saccharomyces
cerevisiae](/wiki/Saccharomyces_cerevisiae "Saccharomyces cerevisiae")_ (also
known as "sugar yeast") species. Within this species are several hundred
different [strains](/wiki/Strain_\(biology\) "Strain \(biology\)") of yeast
that can be used during fermentation to affect the heat or vigor of the
process and enhance or suppress certain flavor characteristics of the
[varietal](/wiki/Varietal "Varietal"). The use of different strains of yeasts
is a major contributor to the diversity of wine, even among the same grape
variety.[6] Alternative, non-_Saccharomyces cerevisiae_ , yeasts are being
used more prevalently in the industry to add greater complexity to wine. After
a winery has been in operation for a number of years, few yeast strains are
actively involved in the fermentation process. The use of active dry yeasts
reduces the variety of strains that appear in spontaneous fermentation by
outcompeting those strains that are naturally present.[7]

The addition of cultured yeast normally occurs with the yeast first in a dried
or "inactive" state and is reactivated in warm water or diluted grape juice
prior to being added to the [must](/wiki/Must "Must"). To thrive and be active
in fermentation, the yeast needs access to a continuous supply of
[carbon](/wiki/Carbon "Carbon"), [nitrogen](/wiki/Yeast_assimilable_nitrogen
"Yeast assimilable nitrogen"), [sulfur](/wiki/Sulfur "Sulfur"),
[phosphorus](/wiki/Phosphorus "Phosphorus") as well as access to various
[vitamins](/wiki/Vitamins "Vitamins") and [minerals](/wiki/Dietary_mineral
"Dietary mineral"). These components are naturally present in the grape
[must](/wiki/Must "Must") but their amount may be corrected by adding
nutrients to the wine, in order to foster a more encouraging environment for
the yeast. Newly formulated time-release nutrients, specifically manufactured
for wine fermentations, offer the most advantageous conditions for yeast.
[Oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen") is needed as well, but in wine making, the
risk of [oxidation](/wiki/Oxidation "Oxidation") and the lack of alcohol
production from oxygenated yeast requires the exposure of oxygen to be kept at
a minimum.[8]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Yeast_and_nutrients.JPG/220px-
Yeast_and_nutrients.JPG)](/wiki/File:Yeast_and_nutrients.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Yeast_and_nutrients.JPG "Enlarge")

Dry winemaking yeast (left) and yeast nutrients used in the rehydration
process to stimulate yeast cells.

Upon the introduction of active yeasts to the grape must,
[phosphates](/wiki/Phosphate "Phosphate") are attached to the sugar and the
six-carbon sugar [molecules](/wiki/Molecule "Molecule") begin to be split into
three-carbon pieces and go through a series of [rearrangement
reactions](/wiki/Rearrangement_reaction "Rearrangement reaction"). During this
process, the [carboxylic](/wiki/Carboxylic "Carboxylic") carbon atom is
released in the form of carbon dioxide with the remaining components becoming
[acetaldehyde](/wiki/Acetaldehyde "Acetaldehyde"). The absence of oxygen in
this [anaerobic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/anaerobic "wikt:anaerobic")
process allows the acetaldehyde to be eventually converted, by reduction, to
[ethanol](/wiki/Ethanol "Ethanol"). During the conversion of acetaldehyde, a
small amount is converted, by oxidation, to [acetic acid](/wiki/Acetic_acid
"Acetic acid") which, in excess, can contribute to the wine fault known as
[volatile acidity](/wiki/Wine_fault#Acetic_acid "Wine fault") (vinegar taint).
After the yeast has exhausted its life cycle, they fall to the bottom of the
fermentation tank as sediment known as [lees](/wiki/Lees_\(fermentation\)
"Lees \(fermentation\)").[9] Yeast ceases its activity whenever all of the
sugar in must has been converted into other chemicals or whenever the alcohol
content has reached 15% alcohol per unit volume; a concentration strong enough
to halt the enzymatic activity of almost all strains of yeast.[10]

### Other compounds
involved[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_in_winemaking&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Other compounds involved")]

The [metabolism](/wiki/Metabolism "Metabolism") of [amino
acids](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid") and breakdown of sugars by yeasts has
the effect of creating other biochemical compounds that can contribute to the
flavor and [aroma of wine](/wiki/Aroma_of_wine "Aroma of wine"). These
compounds can be considered "[volatile](/wiki/Volatile_organic_compound
"Volatile organic compound")" like [aldehydes](/wiki/Aldehyde "Aldehyde"),
[ethyl acetate](/wiki/Ethyl_acetate "Ethyl acetate"), [ester](/wiki/Ester
"Ester"), [fatty acids](/wiki/Fatty_acid "Fatty acid"), [fusel
oils](/wiki/Fusel_oils "Fusel oils"), [hydrogen
sulfide](/wiki/Hydrogen_sulfide "Hydrogen sulfide"), [ketones](/wiki/Ketone
"Ketone") and [mercaptans](/wiki/Mercaptans "Mercaptans") or "non-volatile"
like [glycerol](/wiki/Glycerol "Glycerol"), acetic acid and [succinic
acid](/wiki/Succinic_acid "Succinic acid"). Yeast also has the effect during
fermentation of releasing [glycoside hydrolase](/wiki/Glycoside_hydrolase
"Glycoside hydrolase") which can [hydrolyse](/wiki/Hydrolyse "Hydrolyse") the
flavor precursors of [aliphatics](/wiki/Aliphatics "Aliphatics") (a flavor
component that reacts with [oak](/wiki/Oak_\(wine\) "Oak \(wine\)")),
[benzene](/wiki/Benzene "Benzene") derivatives,
[monoterpenes](/wiki/Monoterpene "Monoterpene") (responsible for floral aromas
from grapes like [Muscat](/wiki/Muscat_\(grape_and_wine\) "Muscat \(grape and
wine\)") and [Traminer](/wiki/Traminer "Traminer")),
[norisoprenoids](/wiki/Norisoprenoid "Norisoprenoid") (responsible for some of
the spice notes in [Chardonnay](/wiki/Chardonnay "Chardonnay")), and
[phenols](/wiki/Natural_phenols_in_wine "Natural phenols in wine").

Some strains of yeasts can generate volatile [thiols](/wiki/Thiol "Thiol")
which contribute to the fruity aromas in many wines such as the
[gooseberry](/wiki/Gooseberry "Gooseberry") scent commonly associated with
[Sauvignon blanc](/wiki/Sauvignon_blanc "Sauvignon blanc").  
_[Brettanomyces](/wiki/Brettanomyces "Brettanomyces")_ yeasts are responsible
for the "barnyard aroma" characteristic in some red wines like
[Burgundy](/wiki/Burgundy_wine "Burgundy wine") and [Pinot
noir](/wiki/Pinot_noir "Pinot noir").[11]

Methanol is not a major constituent of wine. The usual concentration range is
between 0.1 g/liter and 0.2 g/liter. These small traces have no adverse effect
on people and no direct effect on the senses.[12]

## Winemaking
considerations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_in_winemaking&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Winemaking considerations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Fermenting.jpg/220px-
Fermenting.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fermenting.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fermenting.jpg "Enlarge")

Carbon dioxide is visible during the fermentation process in the form of
bubbles in the must.

During fermentation, there are several factors that winemakers take into
consideration, with the most influential to ethanol production being sugar
content in the must, the yeast strain used, and the fermentation
temperature.[13] The biochemical process of fermentation itself creates a lot
of residual [heat](/wiki/Heat "Heat") which can take the must out of the ideal
temperature range for the wine. Typically, white wine is fermented between
18-20 °C (64-68 °F) though a wine maker may choose to use a higher temperature
to bring out some of the complexity of the wine. Red wine is typically
fermented at higher temperatures up to 29 °C (85 °F). Fermentation at higher
temperatures may have adverse effect on the wine in stunning the yeast to
inactivity and even "boiling off" some of the flavors of the wines. Some
winemakers may ferment their red wines at cooler temperatures, more typical of
white wines, in order to bring out more fruit flavors.[9]

To control the heat generated during fermentation, the winemaker must choose a
suitable vessel size or else use a cooling device. Various kinds of cooling
devices are available, ranging from the ancient [Bordeaux](/wiki/Bordeaux_wine
"Bordeaux wine") practice of placing the fermentation vat atop blocks of ice
to sophisticated fermentation tanks that have built-in cooling rings.[14]

A risk factor involved with fermentation is the development of chemical
residue and spoilage which can be corrected with the addition of [sulfur
dioxide](/wiki/Sulfur_dioxide "Sulfur dioxide") (SO2), although excess SO2 can
lead to a wine fault. A winemaker who wishes to make a wine with high levels
of [residual sugar](/wiki/Residual_sugar "Residual sugar") (like a [dessert
wine](/wiki/Dessert_wine "Dessert wine")) may stop fermentation early either
by dropping the temperature of the must to stun the yeast or by adding a high
level of alcohol (like [brandy](/wiki/Brandy "Brandy")) to the must to kill
off the yeast and create a [fortified wine](/wiki/Fortified_wine "Fortified
wine").[9]

The ethanol produced through fermentation acts as an important co-solvent to
the non-polar compound that water cannot dissolve, such as pigments from grape
skins, giving wine varieties their distinct color, and other aromatics.
Ethanol and the acidity of wine act as an inhibitor to bacterial growth,
allowing wine to be safely kept for years in the absence of air.[15]

## Other types of
fermentation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_in_winemaking&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Other types of fermentation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Barrel_fermented_California_Chard.jpg/220px-
Barrel_fermented_California_Chard.jpg)](/wiki/File:Barrel_fermented_California_Chard.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Barrel_fermented_California_Chard.jpg "Enlarge")

A California Chardonnay that shows it has been barrel fermented.

In winemaking, there are different processes that fall under the title of
"Fermentation" but might not follow the same procedure commonly associated
with wine fermentation.

### Bottle
fermentation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_in_winemaking&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Bottle fermentation")]

Bottle fermentation is a method of [sparkling wine
production](/wiki/Sparkling_wine_production "Sparkling wine production"),
originating in the [Champagne](/wiki/Champagne_\(wine_region\) "Champagne
\(wine region\)") region where after the [cuvee](/wiki/Cuvee "Cuvee") has gone
through a primary yeast fermentation the wine is then bottled and goes through
a secondary fermentation where sugar and additional yeast known as _liqueur de
tirage_ is added to the wine. This secondary fermentation is what creates the
carbon dioxide bubbles that sparkling wine is known for.[16]

### Carbonic
maceration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_in_winemaking&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Carbonic maceration")]

The process of [carbonic maceration](/wiki/Carbonic_maceration "Carbonic
maceration") is also known as **whole grape fermentation** where instead of
yeast being added, the grapes fermentation is encouraged to take place inside
the individual grape berries. This method is common in the creation of
[Beaujolais](/wiki/Beaujolais "Beaujolais") wine and involves whole clusters
of grapes being stored in a closed container with the oxygen in the container
being replaced with carbon dioxide.[17] Unlike normal fermentation where yeast
converts sugar into alcohol, carbonic maceration works by enzymes within the
grape breaking down the cellular matter to form [ethanol](/wiki/Ethanol
"Ethanol") and other chemical properties. The resulting wines are typically
soft and fruity.[18]

### Malolactic
fermentation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_in_winemaking&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Malolactic fermentation")]

Instead of yeast, [bacteria](/wiki/Bacteria "Bacteria") play a fundamental
role in [malolactic fermentation](/wiki/Malolactic_fermentation "Malolactic
fermentation") which is essentially the conversion of [malic
acid](/wiki/Malic_acid "Malic acid") into [lactic acid](/wiki/Lactic_acid
"Lactic acid"). This has the benefit of reducing some of the tartness and
making the resulting wine taste softer. Depending on the style of wine that
the winemaker is trying to produce, malolactic fermentation may take place at
the very same time as the yeast fermentation.[19] Alternatively, some strains
of yeast may be developed that can convert L-malate to L-lactate during
alcohol fermentation.[20] For example, _Saccharomyces cerevisiae_ strain ML01
(_S. cerevisiae strain_ ML01), which carries a gene encoding malolactic enzyme
from _Oenococcus oeni_ and a gene encoding malate permease from
_Schizosaccharomyces pombe_. _S. cerevisiae strain_ ML01 has received
regulatory approval in both Canada and the United States.[21]
